node.statement: (Case k=1: Sub-Gaussian exponential moments for linear functionals â€” REPAIRED) Let f in C^inf(T^3). The linear functional phi -> <f, phi> is well-defined under mu since f in H^1(T^3) and the Phi^4_3 field phi in H^{-1+delta}(T^3) mu-a.s. By Barashkov-Gubinelli (2020, arXiv:1805.10814, Theorem 1.1), the Phi^4_3 measure mu on T^3 is constructed via the Boue-Dupuis variational formula, which yields sub-Gaussian tail estimates for linear functionals: for every f in H^1(T^3), there exists C_f > 0 (depending on ||f||_{H^1}) such that P_mu(|<f,phi>| > t) <= 2 exp(-t^2/(2 C_f)) for all t > 0. Equivalently, E_mu[exp(alpha <f,phi>)] <= exp(C_f alpha^2 / 2) < infinity for all alpha in R. This is a direct consequence of the BG variational representation: the Phi^4_3 measure is expressed as the law of phi = X + integral_0^1 u_s ds where X is the GFF and u is an adapted drift solving a variational problem, and the resulting field inherits sub-Gaussian concentration from the underlying Gaussian structure. Note: The relevant external reference is 'Barashkov-Gubinelli variational' (2020) for the torus. The 2021 infinite-volume paper (arXiv:2112.05562) extends this to R^3 but is not needed here.
